instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3330: What is 820-3330? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.GPUVCORE_EN: What is GPUVCORE_EN? GPUVCORE_EN enables GPU VCORE when it is high, a power rail necessary for the GPU to function so you can get an image on the screen. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.820-2915: What is 820-2915? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..

threads.title: MacBook Pro (15-inch, Mid 2012) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Image
threads.message:
Hey guys, I have a 15-inch, Mid 2012 Macbook Pro that came in with no image and I tested it with a known good/working LCD (with working lcd cable too) and there is also no image externally through thunderbolt

[B]This is not the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Retina model with the <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> that needs to be retouched.[/B]

The logic board is spotless on both sides, very well taken care of by customer, customer stated they were using it, shut it off, went to lunch and came back, when he turned it back on, the computer chimed, but there was no image on the screen.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B, I dont think this board is the one with the GPU issues.

The macbook chimes, keyboard lights up, SMC and PRAM work.

Capslock works, external mouse lights up.

One thing I notice is the Sleep Indicator Light (SIL) stays on when the lid is open and/or when the lid is closed.

The voltage for <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is normal at 3.4V

<CHIP>U9701</CHIP> (backlight) is clean and no damage

<CHIP>U8900</CHIP> is clean and no damage either.

Anyone has any clues on what might be the issue?

threads.title: MacBook Pro (15-inch, Mid 2012) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Image
threads.message:
Any history available?
No image, nor backlight?

Disconnect internal LCD, connect to external monitor and give it time to enter OSX; possibly no external video before.

Post voltage for J9000, pins 2/3, 4, 6, 7, 38-40.

threads.title: MacBook Pro (15-inch, Mid 2012) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Image
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 44130"]Any history available?[/QUOTE]

Computer was very well taken care of, battery is in very good condition when it comes to cycles. Kept in a case, very minimal dust inside of machine. Nor any damages on any corner or surface of the machine.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 44130"]No image, nor backlight?[/QUOTE]

Both no image and no backlight, shined light from the back of the lcd, no blinking folder or apple logo.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 44130"]Any history available?
Disconnect internal LCD, connect to external monitor and give it time to enter OSX; possibly no external video before.
[/QUOTE]

Tried that, waited up to 10 minutes for a blinking folder but there is no image, I even connected a hard drive with a hard drive cable and still no image.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 44130"]Any history available?
Post voltage for J9000, pins 2/3, 4, 6, 7, 38-40.
[/QUOTE]
Currently out of the office, will post with voltages in a bit, Do you want voltages with lcd connected and no lcd connected?

Thank you for your support!

threads.title: MacBook Pro (15-inch, Mid 2012) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Image
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 44130"]Any history available?
No image, nor backlight?

Disconnect internal LCD, connect to external monitor and give it time to enter OSX; possibly no external video before.

Post voltage for J9000, pins 2/3, 4, 6, 7, 38-40.
[/QUOTE]

Pin 2/3 - 0.2 MV
Pin 4 - 3.35 V
Pin 6 - 3.35 V
Pin 7 - 3.35 V
Pin 38-40 - 0.02V

Thank You!

threads.title: MacBook Pro (15-inch, Mid 2012) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Image
threads.message: Reflow GMUX and see what happens...

threads.title: MacBook Pro (15-inch, Mid 2012) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Image
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 44166"]Reflow GMUX and see what happens...[/QUOTE]

I was thinking about replacing <CHIP>U8900</CHIP>, do you think it might be the issue? Or does GMUX send those signals?

Are there any voltages around the <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> you want me to send you?

threads.title: MacBook Pro (15-inch, Mid 2012) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Image
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8900</CHIP> is not a common issue on this board.
Do you get GPU voltage?
Reflow it if not.
But you should reflow GMUX...

threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 44171"]<CHIP>U8900</CHIP> is not a common issue on this board.
Do you get GPU voltage?
Reflow it if not.
But you should reflow GMUX...[/QUOTE]

To test GPU voltage I check <SIGNAL>GPUVCORE_EN</SIGNAL> or <SIGNAL>GPUVCORE_PGOOD</SIGNAL>?

I reflowed it but still nothing?

MacBook Pro (15-inch, Mid 2012) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Image
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 44173"]"Do you get GPU voltage?"
L8930/60...[/QUOTE]

Hello and happy new year! I will check that when I get back into the office, I did discover a bit of corrosion under the <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> when removing the edge bonding, so I am currently trying to find a stencil to reball the old chip or I have to find another. Will a <CHIP>U9600</CHIP> from a 2011 15" work on a 2012? (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2915</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> GMUX on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>)

Please let me know.

threads.title: MacBook Pro (15-inch, Mid 2012) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Image
threads.message:
I recommned you to get GMUX from the same donor board, as it has firmware.

Please do NOT quote an entire post from few cm above...

threads.title: MacBook Pro (15-inch, Mid 2012) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Image
threads.message: Alright, if I dont have a gmux from the same donor board (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>), is there any place I can get one such as a reputable online supplier or can I use one from the 2011?

threads.title: MacBook Pro (15-inch, Mid 2012) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Image
threads.message:
Buy scrap boards from eBay, or Aliexpress.
Or contact Paul Lee through Skype.
Is the same galaxyelectronics2015 from eBay.

threads.title: MacBook Pro (15-inch, Mid 2012) <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3330</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B No Image
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 44173"]"Do you get GPU voltage?"
L8930/60...[/QUOTE]


L8930 
PIN 1 - .9 V
PIN 2 - .9 V

L8960
PIN 1 - .9 V
PIN 2 - .9 V

Looks like I am getting Voltage,

I also replaced GMUX with a new one from a donor board of the same board number and text on it.

I am getting 0V on output on <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> (LCD LVDS INTERFACE)

Pin 1 - 0V (<SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL>)
Pin 2/3 (IN) - 3.4V
Pin 4,5 - 0V
